Topic.Title: T4 is so late, it is really DOA

Message.Msg: "Technically correct is the best kind of correct." Those other ARM processors are not A15 cores. They are more than competitive with the A9 but seem to be, on average, slower than the A15 at the same clock rate. They have different performance characteristics and it's easy to find a specific benchmark that shows a favorite one (or more likely, a specific compiler optimization) winning. Apple, Qualcomm, Samsung and Nvidia are leapfrogging each other in performance. I do expect the Tegra 4 to briefly have a supportable claim to top performance, but be matched in March or April by Samsung with a quad Exynos 5 with a slightly higher clock rate. Both to displaced soon after. The interesting competitive positioning will evolve late next year when the ARM v8 implementations hit the market. Within a few months the market will decide if the A15's PAE addressing is a good enough hack, or if everyone should just switch to 64 bits. My guess is the latter will happen. If so, the investment in in-house ARMv7 implementations will be mostly devalued.

Topic.Title: whosunw - Project Denver

Message.Msg: AMCC just taped out its first 40nm ARMv8 based chip. Everything at public demos was running on FPGAs. AMCC has a loooonnnng way to go before its product is viable for anything but ultra-low-end cheap products.

Topic.Title: Nvidia's CES 2013 1/6/13 Press Conference Topics - Tegra, Geforce, Geforce Grid

Message.Msg: Typical Nvidia launch at CES... nvidia announces a new chip (tegra #4) -- but nothing for sale. Delay #1 nvidia re-announces the same new chip This time with "launch partners" -- usually Asus and/or ZTE -- and nobody else Delay #2 Mysterious, unexplained delay #3 Non-disclosure agreements required of OEM's Delay #4 Paper re-launch debut of new chip Jen waves prototype of something in the air, hastily assembled with wood screws Somebody from nvidia with the title of "Interim" reads the following, "We may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially." Jen then announces a possible doubling of revenue due to the new chip Still no chips or products actually seen PowerPoint slides of Nvidia Roadmap get revisions made to the years previously shown First new product finally arrives on the market First new product Recalled days later Mysterious lengthly delay #5 Long parade of cancellations of nvidia's prior "wins" begins Nvidia provides a list of improbable excuses for this and that "Volcanic clouds" is one of Jen's all-time Best excuses for having no chips to sell Yet no other semiconductor maker was impacted by Jen's purported "Volcanic clouds" Blame is assigned to the aforementioned improbable third parties Anyone actually nvidia increases the nomenclature on the commercial failure part by +one (Tegra #5) Repeat process annually at CES

Message.Title: NVIDIA TegraZone App Launches On Windows RT
Message.Msg: Owners of quad-core Tegra 3 Android tablets like the Nexus 7 and ASUS Transformer Prime have enjoyed NVIDIA’s TegraZone app on their devices for some time. The mobile gaming destination is now available for Tegra 3-powered Windows RT devices like Microsoft‘s own Surface and the ASUS VivoTab RT. NVIDIA TegraZone Windows RT Why call it a “destination?” NVIDIA has done an excellent job with their Android version of Tegrazone by highlighting existing and upcoming Tegra 3-enhanced games, but keeping the shameless self-promotion balanced with general industry news and advice. For example, the Windows RT version of TegraZone advertises games like SoulCraft, Riptide GP, and Great Big War Game, but also contains starter guides and tips for new Windows RT users. If their history with Android is any indication, the app should evolve into an enjoyable portal for gaming news on multiple platforms, but tailored to Windows RT users. It’s widely acknowledged that Windows RT is still starving for apps, but it’s an ideal platform for high-quality mobile games. NVIDIA’s developer relations team is 100+ staff members strong, and they’re dedicated to working with developers as they create games tailored for the quad-core Tegra 3. After all, the more appealing a Tegra 3 platform becomes, the more opportunity for NVIDIA to profit. Hopefully the arrival of TegraZone in the Windows Store will usher in a wave of developer support and new titles. NVIDIA’s Tegra 3 chip allows game developers to deliver enhanced graphical effects like particles, realistic physics, and dynamic lighting. In most cases the differences are nuanced but noticeable, especially for gamers desiring the best version of a game. TegraZone is now available on all Windows RT devices. Just open your Charms bar and seek it out.

Message.Title: Fudzilla
Message.Msg: Wayne, also known as Tegra 4 is coming out at CES 2013, or in some 10 days from now. Nvidia has an event planned days ahead of CES 2013 and the company will likely show some tablets and hybrids based on the new Tegra SoC. Let’s call Wayne Tegra 4 before it gets official. Nvidia had Wayne ready to launch in Q4 2012 but it had to wait for partners to release the designs based on it, and most of them wanted to do it at CES 2013. European phones based on Wayne are going to show up in February, at the Mobile World Congress. This is the first quad-core A15 design that will bring a significant performance increase over Tegra 3 and we are hearing that the four-plus-one core will deliver a bigger performance boost than Tegra 3 did over Tegra 2. Also, the fact that the new chip is 28nm and supports DDR3L also promises more efficiency. USB 3.0 support is something that is getting us excited as usually it is quite slow to transfer anything onto tablets, phones and hybrids. USB 3.0 on tablets will significantly increase the data transfer speed and Tegra 4 will be among the first chips to feature USB 3.0 support, and many consumers will appreciate faster data transfer rates. The other thing that got our attention is dual display support and you will be able to have two independent screens. On Tegra 3 based devices, you can only mirror the output, not display two independent screens. It could be a very interesting feature for dockable devices. You can read more here.

Message.Title: Upward Adjusted Kindle Fire and Nexus 7 Tablet Orders
Message.Msg: Quanta Computer has upward adjusted its forecast tablet shipments for 2012 from 13-14 million units originally to 15 million units mainly due to increased ODM orders for Kindle Fire and Nexus 7, the Chinese-language newspaper Economic Daily News (EDN) has cited company vice chairman CC Leung as indicating. Source: Digitimes
